Literature Review: Gas-liquid foams are complex soft materials that exhibit fascinating physical properties and have a wide range of applications across various industries. These foams consist of gas bubbles dispersed in a continuous liquid phase, stabilized by surfactants or particles at the gas-liquid interfaces. The unique structure and behavior of foams have attracted significant research interest in recent years, with studies focusing on understanding their dynamics, rheology, and multiscale nature.One of the key aspects of foam dynamics is the interplay between microscopic structural elements and macroscopic behavior. Cantat et al. (2013) provided a comprehensive overview of foam physics, emphasizing the importance of understanding bubble-scale processes to predict bulk foam properties. Their work highlighted the role of surface tension, capillary forces, and thin film dynamics in determining foam stability and flow characteristics.The rheology of foams is particularly intriguing due to their viscoelastic nature. Denkov et al. (2009) investigated the relationship between foam structure and rheological properties, demonstrating that factors such as bubble size distribution, liquid fraction, and surface elasticity significantly influence the foam's response to applied stresses. They found that foams exhibit both solid-like and liquid-like behavior, depending on the magnitude and duration of the applied stress.The dynamics of foam under steady shear flow has been extensively studied as a model system for understanding complex fluid behavior. Goyon et al. (2008) conducted experiments on confined foam flows, revealing the existence of non-local effects in foam rheology. Their findings challenged traditional continuum descriptions and highlighted the need for more sophisticated models that account for mesoscale structural elements.Interfacial instabilities play a crucial role in foam dynamics, particularly in processes such as foam generation and destruction. Langevin (2017) reviewed the physicochemical aspects of foam stability, focusing on the mechanisms of film rupture and coalescence. The author emphasized the importance of surface rheology and interfacial viscoelasticity in determining foam stability and lifetime.The fracture of foams through bubble rupture is another important aspect of foam dynamics. Hutzler et al. (2014) investigated the mechanics of foam fracture, demonstrating that the process involves a complex interplay between elastic deformation, plastic rearrangements, and bubble coalescence. Their work provided insights into the relationship between foam structure and fracture toughness, which is crucial for understanding foam failure mechanisms in various applications.Network modeling approaches have emerged as powerful tools for describing foam dynamics at the mesoscale. Durian (1995) developed a bubble model that treats foams as a network of interacting bubbles, capturing essential features of foam rheology and dynamics. This approach has been further refined and extended by subsequent researchers to incorporate more realistic bubble interactions and structural rearrangements.Continuum models with elastoviscoplastic constitutive relations have also been developed to describe foam behavior at larger scales. Balmforth et al. (2014) reviewed various continuum models for yield stress fluids, including foams, and discussed their applicability to different flow regimes. These models provide a framework for predicting foam behavior in complex geometries and under various loading conditions.The multiscale nature of foams presents both challenges and opportunities for developing comprehensive theoretical descriptions. Höhler and Cohen-Addad (2005) discussed the bridging of microscopic and macroscopic approaches in foam physics, emphasizing the need for integrating structural information across different length scales. Their work highlighted the potential of foams as model systems for developing multiscale modeling strategies applicable to other complex materials.Recent advances in experimental techniques have greatly enhanced our ability to study foam dynamics at multiple scales. Guo et al. (2013) utilized X-ray tomography to investigate the three-dimensional structure and dynamics of foams under various conditions. Their work provided unprecedented insights into bubble rearrangements, coarsening processes, and the evolution of foam structure over time.In conclusion, the study of gas-liquid foam dynamics represents a rich and multifaceted field of research that continues to yield important insights into the behavior of complex soft materials. The interplay between structural elements at the mesoscale and continuum descriptions at larger scales offers a unique opportunity to develop rigorous multiscale modeling approaches. As research in this area progresses, it is likely to have far-reaching implications not only for foam science but also for our understanding of other complex fluids and soft materials.
